mia workshop in EuroBioC2024

Source: vignettes/mia_demo.Rmd
mia_demo.Rmd

Authors: Tuomas Borman1, Leo Lahti2.
Last modified: 12 August, 2024.

Overview

Description

This workshop introduces the miaverse, a SummarizedExperiment framework tailored for microbiome data science. Participants will gain hands-on experience with the TreeSummarizedExperiment class, which is central to the miaverse framework. In this session, we will also learn how to utilize miaverse methods and navigate the Orchestrating Microbiome Analysis (OMA) online book for additional resource.

We will start with a brief overview of the framework, followed by an instructor-led live demonstration. The demonstration will showcase selected key features and functionalities of miaverse. After the demo, participant will have time to discuss the framework, ask questions, and explore the tools and methods covered.

By the end of the workshop, attendees will have a understanding of how to apply the miaverse framework to their microbiome data analysis and will be well-prepared to further explore the framework independently.

Pre-requisites

  • Basic knowledge of R coding
  • Familiarity with Bioconductor
  • Understanding of microbiome research

If your time allows, we recommend to spend some time to explore Orchestrating Microbiome Analysis (OMA) online book.

Participation

Participants are encouraged to ask questions at any time during the workshop to facilitate a more interactive learning experience. The workshop will follow a demo from the OMA online book, and participants will be guided through hands-on exercises.

Bioconductor provides pre-installed virtual machines with all necessary packages. These machines will allow participants to run the workshop exercises and follow along with the instructor.

R / Bioconductor packages used

In this workshop, we will focus on the usage of the mia package, which is designed for microbiome data science. This package is part of the Bioconductor project and provides essential tools for analyzing microbiome data using the SummarizedExperiment framework.

Time outline

Activity Time
Background 10m
Demo 20m
Questions and free exploration 10m

Workshop goals and objectives

Learning goals

  • Understand miaverse: Gain insight into the miaverse framework and its role within the SummarizedExperiment framework.

  • Use TreeSummarizedExperiment: Learn to use the TreeSummarizedExperiment class for microbiome data analysis.

  • Access resources: Get familiar with additional tools and resources, including the OMA online book.

Learning objectives

  • Analyze and apply methods: Use the miaverse framework to process microbiome data and apply methods.

  • Create visualizations: Generate and interpret visualizations of microbiome data with miaverse.

  • Explore documentation: Navigate the OMA online book for additional tools and methods.

Workshop

1 Background

The SummarizedExperiment (SE) is a widely used data container in Bioconductor, applicable across various fields. It fosters synergy by enabling the use of shared methods and standardized formats, which facilitates collaborative research and reduces redundant efforts.

SummarizedExperiment class

However, microbiome data science relied on alternative approaches. To integrate microbiome data science within the SE ecosystem, the TreeSummarizedExperiment (TreeSE) was developed.

TreeSummarizedExperiment class

Subsequently, a suite of mia* (MIcrobiome Analysis) packages was developed to offer microbiome-specific methods within the SE ecosystem:

  • mia: Data analysis.
  • miaViz: Visualization.
  • miaSim: Data simulation.
  • miaTime: Time series analysis (coming soon to Bioconductor).

The framework has been further expanded by various independent developers, introducing a range of additional methods. For more details, see OMA.

To support microbiome data science, the online book Orchestrating Microbiome Analysis with Bioconductor (OMA) was created. It aims to help users conduct microbiome data science by providing examples and best practices developed through collaborative efforts. The book will soon be published on Bioconductor.

2 Demonstration

In this demo, we will follow the introductory workflow from OMA by copy-pasting code examples provided there. The goal is not only to familiarize participants with the TreeSE and related methods but also to introduce them to OMA, supporting their learning beyond the workshop.

3 Q&A and free exploration

Time for questions. You are also encouraged to explore and run examples from OMA on your own.
